23/09/2021, 13:17 - Mayokun: Guys please I need your help. I want to put out a post for people just starting out in the data science space

I feel this is the best place to get some advice from some experts here.

Iâ€™ll really love to hear some of your opinions on this.

*What advice would you give anyone just starting out in the data science space?*




@2348108522573 @2348065935396 @2348160626971 @2347085316273 @2348108316393 @2348120919501 @2347033167142 @2349067500316
23/09/2021, 13:27 - Olayinka: As an aspiring Data Scientist, I will highlight briefly two major challenges you will face:
1. Information Overload.
2. Impostor Syndrome.

Due to the plethora of information available now. There are lots of free online courses, trainings, materials. Personally, I am a beneficiary of several FREE online courses. I have done about 23 free courses with Coursera, 1 with Udacity, several ones with Udemy etc.
As you begin and continue your journey, there is high possibility to get swamped in the amount of resources at your disposal. You will be faced with which course I should do. If a new free course or training comes up, you will want to jump on that and all these causes distractions.

So what should I do?
FOCUS.
Set out your goals clearly for a time. Be focused to attend trainings, take courses that align to your goals for that time.
*However, you can archive some of these courses for another time*

The next issue stems from the first. Impostor syndrome is simple terms is when you don't appreciate the progress you are making or have made due to what others are doing.
You should get it clear that everyone has set goals for themselves and so you should not feel intimidated by what others are doing.

Ask yourself these questions.
Am I making progress?
Do I achieve my set goals?

A sincere answer to these questions will see you appreciate more what you have done and forge ahead to achieve more.

~ Diaries of an aspiring Data Scientist
23/09/2021, 13:27 - Olayinka: I shared this one time with one lady
23/09/2021, 13:27 - Olayinka: @2348133127971, I don't know if this works
23/09/2021, 13:31 - +234 708 531 6273: From my perspective:

1.Understand basics of Python/R , SQL, and Statistics like the back of your palm.

2. Pick a domain(NLP, Computer Vision or your traditional ML). Don't be  a generalist . Master a domain and have a brief understanding of others.

3. Join DBT Nigeria.  As a data scientist,  knowing how to build data pipelines using the modern data stack will put you miles ahead of others. Eventually,  you might even dump data science for AE when you realise most Nigerian companies are not ready infrastructure wise.

*Requirements*
- Bachelors in engineering, or equivalent
3 to 5 years of demonstrated experience deploying and supporting public cloud Infrastructure (GCP as primary) with hybrid cloud environments

- Ability to manage many cases simultaneously, prioritizing appropriately
Manage the cloud infrastructure environment through cross technology administration (OS , Storage, virtual networks, load balancers, IAM, policies) , execution of scripting and monitoring automations.

- Manage the environment incidents with a focus on service restoration.
Experience with Cloud IaaS & DevOps Platforms like Terraform, Automation or equivalent technology

- Ability to communicate with customers, developers, and other disciplines of systems administration

- Periodic 24x7 on-call availability


*Job Requirements*
- Experience with public cloud infrastructures, Google Cloud IaaS services
Google Cloud Professional (GCP), Microsoft Azure or other public cloud provider
Certifications in any of the following: GCP Certified Associate Engineer, GCP Certified Solutions Architect, MCSA Cloud Platform, MCSA Azure Solutions Architect or equivalent cloud certification

- Hands on Experience and understanding of Google Cloud Infrastructure, primarily on IaaS model

- Experience with any of the Configuration Management (Cloud shell, Jenkins, Ansible)

- Experience with Cloud Formation Templates, Terraform, etc.

- Hands on Experience with GCP Foundation, Storage bucket, Backup, Disaster Recovery, VPC networks, IAM, Stack driver, troubleshooting and Cloud Security.

- Experience with managed code or scripting competency (PowerShell, Python, JSON, and YML)

- Understand the requirement & Plan/Design/Execute new strategy/projects in GCP

- Experience with continuous Cost Optimization in GCP

- Knowledge/Experience with GCP PaaS services

- Hands on Experience in managing on premise and public cloud infrastructure in a hybrid environment.

- Participate in Sev1, Sev2 incident calls, work with Team towards resolving the issues on premise (DC) and in Google Cloud

- Excellent communication skills

- Self-disciplined and highly motivated


*Location:* (Egbeda, Lagos, Nigeria) Onsite and Remote.

*Apply here:* https://forms.office.com/r/eZ8JCeTiHY

Submit CV to kayodeojo@bytesedu.com.ng

03/10/2021, 23:33 - +234 818 368 5814: Please I need enlightenment on ETL or ELT  â˜¹ï¸â˜¹ï¸â˜¹ï¸
03/10/2021, 23:42 - +234 818 368 5814: @2347085316273
03/10/2021, 23:48 - +234 708 531 6273: Extract (E) - Picking the data from its source eg For Twitter data, you need to extract it with Twitter API . That process of extraction is the E

Transform(T) ... The data is coming with many fields (date field, no of likes , retweets etc) but you only need retweets. The process of removing the others you don't need or doing modifications on it is the Transform

Load(L)- After transforming, you want to save it or use it  somewhere e.g MYSQL data base. That process of saving it is the load. 

I hope I was able to simplify it enough
03/10/2021, 23:50 - +234 708 531 6273: ELT or ETL is just how you prefer to sequence the operations
03/10/2021, 23:51 - +234 818 368 5814: â¤ï¸
03/10/2021, 23:53 - +234 818 368 5814: Please I need resources for any cloud platform 

Preferably, GCP

05/10/2021, 10:54 - +234 708 531 6273: No resources per se 

No single resource speaks to Data Engineering as a whole.

From my understanding,  DE has distinct areas and different resources speak to these different areas. 

We have

1.Warehousing 
2.Event driven Systems 
3.Search Analytics systems   
4. Batch and stream processing systems

To mention a few. As the use case arises then you know where to turn to. 
Also, It is worth mentioning that these distinct areas have both on-premise and cloud services/tools. It is a very wide ocean . No one can provision an all encompassing material yet.  If you want something on a particular  area then maybe I can recommend

05/10/2021, 11:45 - Francis Atoyebi: <Media omitted>
05/10/2021, 11:46 - Olayinka: This NoSQL is one area I need to check out
05/10/2021, 11:47 - +234 708 531 6273: Hmmn I get you but at the end of the end you might not end up working with the one you learnt

For me, I can query any SQL DB even though I haven't worked with it before. I just look for the minor differences online when I hit a stumbling block . For example, to extract month from a date column has different function name across various DBs. I just need to look it up on Google for that particular Database and I move on. The query concept is almost the same across board. 

For NoSQL, It is tricky. We  have Document type, columnar, graph and the likes so there is no one cap fits all here. However, I think document types nosql are the most common in production. Both Elasticsearch and Mongo DB are document type dbs so yes learninh one of them will be great.

Learning SQL first for starters is the best.
05/10/2021, 12:09 - +234 816 062 6971: Awesome 
I agree with you.
Google was my life saver the last time I worked on Data Migration using the SQL I am not that family with

I guess using ORM can make sense if applicable. This means basically querying in your language of choice, you write the codes in Python but the library is actually executing SQL query of choice in the backend. It has pros and cons sha. I used this for a project.

05/10/2021, 12:50 - Fabiyi Opeyemi: The reason is they want Analytics to be easy and no code as much as possible and SQL seem to be something anyone can pickup. So everything seems to be revolving around SQL

So most DE thought leaders believe the future will be SQL based. Everyone want an Infrastructure that can easily be setup without stress and all, and less headache for Data Engineers and all, so they focus more on business impacting stuff. 


So the koko is just learn what you need on the fly and be ready to quickly adapt to new ways of doing stuff

cra.[Date_Completed],

cra.[Score]

FROM [Rpt_DataSources].[HR].[vw_Contracts_Denormalised_With_Custom_Att_rpt] cd

LEFT OUTER JOIN [Data_Warehouse01].[HR].[Fact_CV19_Risk_Asmnt] cra ON [CoreHR_Employee_ID] = [CoreHRID]

LEFT OUTER JOIN [Data_Warehouse01].[HR].[Dim_Person] dp ON [CoreHR_Employee_ID] = [CoreHR_EmployeeID]

WHERE Is_Current = 1

 

),cte_counts  as  (

select distinct

CoreHR_Employee_ID,

count (Date_Completed) assessments

from cte_contracts

group by CoreHR_Employee_ID,

Work_Location_ID,

FirstName,

Surname

having count (Date_Completed) > 1

)

select distinct

cd.CoreHR_Employee_ID,

cd.[Employment_Status],

dp.FirstName,

dp.Surname,

cd.[Job_Title_ProperCase],

cd.Work_Location_ID,

cd.Work_Location,

cc.[Date_Completed],

cc.[Score]

FROM [Rpt_DataSources].[HR].[vw_Contracts_Denormalised_With_Custom_Att_rpt] cd

inner join cte_counts c ON c.CoreHR_Employee_ID = cd.CoreHR_Employee_ID

inner join cte_contracts cc ON cc.CoreHR_Employee_ID = cd.CoreHR_Employee_ID

inner join [Data_Warehouse01].HR.Dim_Person dp on CoreHR_EmployeeID = c.CoreHR_Employee_ID

WHERE cd.Is_Current = 1

order BY Work_Location_ID,CoreHR_Employee_ID

I have some questions â˜ºï¸

1. What factors/ data point does one consider when building a forecasting model to predict future sales of a company.

2. What would be the thought process for someone who would want to find out why there has been a sudden surge in the number of inbound call to customer care line.

09/10/2021, 20:03 - +234 708 531 6273: 1. The variable you are measuring (e.g Sales, customer visit , revenue, interactions etc  ) and the time stamp of occurrence of the variable in question. 

2. There might be other indicators/factors that a timestamp might not be able to give you. A time stamp most times speaks to anomalies with respect time. What a time series /forecasting model might tell you is the present of seasonality in your data and how values change at every given timeframe(hours , days, months or years). If what you are looking for is to predict a particular time frame when calls will be higher/lower, then a forecasting/timeseries model might be ideal.  But If you are interested in the why, you need more data points/variables as timestamp alone is not enough indicator

10/10/2021, 10:44 - +234 708 531 6273: First thing is that Correlation is not the same as Causation. 

Correlation simply means that an increase/decrease in a particular variable is consistent (to a certain degree as shown by the percentages) with an increase/decrease in another variable.  

For example, you will see some 100%s, this means that the variable perfectly correlates with itself which is an ideal situation as the values are the same on both axes. 
For others, the degree at which they correlate which each other varies and the more the correlation the higher the score(%). 

You should try watching videos on YouTube for a more exhaustive explanation.

Rosie and I spoke last night after the event (you people crushing you see you don't have hope ğŸ˜‚), and she was saying how Drew (Cofounder ) and Tristan (2nd Cofounder) were amazed that they've never had this kind of turnout in any first meetup anywhere in the last 5 years of the company, and they love the energy. So, yeah all eyes on Nigeria dbt community. 

One of my major goal why I wanted that meetup to happen with support from everyone was to let everyone see and start thinking global, so while you are building your skills don't limit yourself to what's see obtainable alone in the Nigerian market but how to be a global talent after securing the bag here in Nigeria (first rough it to get something paying bills here ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚), and continue to grind. Keep shooting those applications and get used to rejection. 

Few things to note for the sake of those that may be new to the whole dbt and Modern data stack;

1. For newbies, beginners and enthusiast - Don't pressure yourself by stopping any of your current learning to jumping at dbt immediately learning. The essence of the meetup and Information is to make you aware that there's more as you continue to learn, so you don't think you have arrived and a badass Data Analyst or Scientist because you can use few tools, there's always more to stay relevant.  

So continue your initial learning and go at your pace, no pressure, take it one step at a time, learn the fundamental very very well, and when the time comes you will know when to learn dbt or any other tools. 

That's why you have a community like this to help guide your learning 

2. For the intermediate and boss with strong fundamentals and all, I guess it's time to add dbt to your toolkit and most importantly start shooting those global jobs. 

Stay glued to #jobs channel, and continue to apply. Let me open secret @2347085316273 applied to one some days ago and baba don get Interview invite, so yeah don't dull yourself, you will get rejected a couple of time but trust me you don't know which one will be the golden one. 

3. Join other exciting channels, network, meet people beyond your space. I guess this one is left to you. Comment on people's question that you have answers to, that's how you gain relevance in a community and people know you. Show yourself ooo you don't know who is looking at you and following all your responses across different channels. 

I personally have a long list of channels I subscribed to and I am very active. I have various subgroup that we hold weekly zoom meeting to catchup and bond and we all met in that channel. One wanted me to join his team sef. In summary play your game,  build your brand, and I think for anyone that can maximize and use that community well you stand to enjoy a lot. I devote 30min every night to read all important chats in some channels and respond if I have answers and all.

I believe some times after learning and doing the hard work, you also need to position yourself well too.  

4. The Brooklyn Data team has shared the link to the job. Like I said they want to recruit some Nigerians to join their team and I will be dropping the link in the #local-Nigeria. Hopefully you can tell those not in this community to join, I will be dropping other vital information as it relate to dbt there, so if you aren't there sorry if you miss out ğŸ˜‚ (I won't bring some goodies here). The goal of the #local-nigeria is to give room for other people that are unable to join this group to gain access to quality information too. So encourage others not on this group to join that channel


Thank you once again â˜ºï¸

Danke!

let's say you run a bank and you have the data of inflows your customers have received for the past 1 year, what kind of insights will you like to get from the data? 

The data contains the beneficiary account, sender account,  sender bank name, bvn,amount, date generated, Transaction status(Failed or Successful), the date customer account was opened, beneficiary account type etc .

I av already done things like:
1. Which banks are we getting the highest inflow from
2. Which customer package is getting the most inflow
3. Why are transactions unsuccessful? What are the error messages? Etc

19/10/2021, 18:41 - +234 816 062 6971: For example 
A nomenclature could be-

Potential: customers with high potential to enter the loyal customer segments, you can entice them with some benefits

Promising: showing promising signs with quantity and value of their transactions but it has been a while since they last made a transaction with your bank.

Needs Attention: made some initial transactions at the early time of the year or month but have not seen them active. Probably they are not okay with the banks customer service or so. You may want to try to get feedback from them.

Require Attention: these are the poorest performers, they might have gone to the bankâ€™s competitors for now. You may need new strategies to win them back.

Others include Champions, Loyal and others 

This is just a nomenclature that I chose

23/10/2021, 21:38 - Ayomiposi Sodeinde: Write code (python and R) to output the list of results from calculating the mean score from 10 throws of a 6 sided dice run 5 times.

So throw a dice 10 times and calculate the mean and repeat this 5 times resulting in a list/array of 5 numbers.
23/10/2021, 21:40 - Ayomiposi Sodeinde: Cookies either contain bits of candy or they don't, the probability of a cookie being a candy cookie is 9/10

If a cookie is a candy cookie then the probability of taking a bite without a piece of candy is 1/3

If a cookie is randomly selected and a bite taken that does not contain candy what is the probability that the bite came from a candy cookie?
23/10/2021, 21:53 - Abiodun Sanni: This is a conditional probability problem
23/10/2021, 21:53 - Abiodun Sanni: You can read about Bayes theorem online
23/10/2021, 21:54 - Abiodun Sanni: For this, the program must be in both Python & R??
23/10/2021, 21:54 - Ayomiposi Sodeinde: Preferably Python
23/10/2021, 21:54 - Ayomiposi Sodeinde: Priority is Python
23/10/2021, 21:57 - +234 809 183 1446: get_mean <- function() {
  dice = NULL
  for (i in 1:10) {
    dice[i] = sample(1:6, 1, replace = TRUE)
    
  }
  
  mean(dice)
}

replicate(5, get_mean())
23/10/2021, 21:57 - +234 809 183 1446: This is in R tho
23/10/2021, 21:57 - Abiodun Sanni: For R:

Answers <- NULL
for (i in 1:5) {

result <- sample(1:6, 10, repeat = T)
c <- mean(result)
Answers <- append(Answers, c)

}

Answers = [ ]

26/10/2021, 00:43 - +234 818 368 5814: Who can explain the concept of KYC and VOC in Data Analysis Project 

@2348108522573 @2348065935396 @2347085316273 @2348160626971 etal
26/10/2021, 09:27 - +234 708 145 1890: VoC is Voice of Customer right?
26/10/2021, 09:28 - +234 818 368 5814: Yes
26/10/2021, 09:40 - +234 708 145 1890: Coming from a Customer Care and Product perspective...

KYC and VoC is used to improve customer experience.

So, if you have a good KYC and VoC in place, you should be able to know uniqueness of each customer and provide the experience customised to them.

For Analytics, KYC and VoC allows you segment your customer appropriately and then you can do drill downs and drill throughs to find out uniqueness per customer segment, you can recommend or build new products based on this.

If you have done KYC and VoC well, you should be able to trace a customer history around all systems available.
26/10/2021, 09:40 - +234 708 145 1890: I don't know if you get my drift?

29/10/2021, 15:58 - Fabiyi Opeyemi: Caveat dey the post sha
29/10/2021, 15:58 - Fabiyi Opeyemi: Don't do it frequently
29/10/2021, 15:59 - Mayokun: Yeah, when companies see that you move too often, itâ€™s a concern
29/10/2021, 15:59 - Mayokun: They want loyaltyğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚
29/10/2021, 15:59 - +234 703 806 5681: Reasonably true if you're chasing salary.

If you're chasing status, it can actually hinder growth.

Find a balance. Max of 2 years per place, then move, if you're following this pattern. This should be within the first 5-6 years of your career.

It'll cover about 3 different companies. Should give you enough exposure.

Then pick the 4th place, hopefully at a reasonably senior position and plan to stay for a longer time, if their growth prospects is cool.

In the end you won't want to spend all your life chasing money. At some point you probably want to be at the level where you can be a director in other companies, CEO, Partner or whatever.
29/10/2021, 15:59 - +234 703 806 5681: That's your career talk for today.

30/10/2021, 13:27 - +234 816 381 5935: Okay
30/10/2021, 15:05 - +234 816 381 5935: You can use this code: I don't know if it solves your problem sha.. 

final_PortfolioName = []
a = []
b = []
c = []
for i in df:
    PortfolioName = i.split("|")[0]
    for j in i.split("|")[1].split(","):
        var1 = j.split(":")[0]
        var2 = j.split(":")[1]
        var3 = j.split(":")[2]
        
        a.append(var1)
        b.append(var2)
        c.append(var3)
        
    final_PortfolioName.append(PortfolioName)

17/11/2021, 08:57 - +234 816 062 6971: Yeah, it depends on domain
It might not seem right to say there is a particular value one must always use. It depends on the situation or the threshold you fill works for you, if you decrease your level of significance, the larger your confidence interval and lower your chances of rejecting the null hypothesis. You have to also have it in mind that statistical significance doesnâ€™t imply practical significance, for example a difference of 0.5kg in weight of 2 humans might be statistically significant but to us as humans, we will be like they way the same, the difference is not a big deal.

I might be wrong ğŸ¤”

24/11/2021, 15:57 - Fabiyi Opeyemi: Since they organize event they can use a CRM like customer.io or any of the available tools that will connect to say event brite created for each report to generate the Google sheets. 

So major tables to create ;

1.  Volunteers table which is dimension.  So each volunteer has and as the number of volunteer increases the table get updated 

2. Committe table - Iâ€™m assuming for a yearly event it prolly will be hosted at different countries and different volunteers will plan with.  This table will host different activity and role thatâ€™s available for different Volunteers to participate. This table will be the upstream model to help track the activities of all volunteers since a volunteer can be active in one capacity last year and take more responsibility this year. 

This table will have a many to one relationship to the Volunteers table. You can also choose to denormalize it. 


3. Events Table. - This will just host information about each year event like ;

Country the event was hosted 
Number of volunteers
No of attendees
Event_id. 

4.  Attendance table which will be the Fact table will host all the details of all attendees and will have fields such as ;

Event-id link to the Event table 
All participants info like name etc. 

Is_committe - A boolean feature to identify whether the participants is a volunteer or not 

Committe-id this will apply to those with is_committe =True. 

This will host all yearly attendance and all.

dbt for your modeling and transformation

What's a "I like this. I want this" for you and what's "this is interesting"

05/12/2021, 16:38 - Abiodun Sanni: ## Checking Primes from 2 to n
def isItPrime(n):
    if n < 2:
        print('Not a valid number')

    else:
        for k in range(2,n+1):
            flag = 0
            for i in range(2,int(k/2)+1):
                if (k % i)==0 and k != i:
                    j = int(k/i)
                    flag = 1
                    #print('{} = {} * {}'.format(k,i,j))
                    break
            if flag == 0:
                print('{} is a prime number'.format(k))
            else:
                print('{} = {} * {}'.format(k,i,j))

You want to get the list of dates between the dates & date_diff with the start date inclusive.

09/12/2021, 18:35 - +234 809 183 1446: library(tidyverse)

sample_data <- tribble(
    ~s_n, ~date, ~day_diff,
    ########################
    1, "2021/07/18",3,
    2,"2021/07/25",2,
    3,"2021/08/01",3,
    4,"2021/08/11",2
) %>% 
    mutate(date = as.Date(date))


sample_data %>% 
    mutate(dates = map2(date,
                        day_diff,
                        .f = function(date,diff){
                            date - seq(0,diff-1)
                        })) %>% 
    unnest(dates) %>% 
    select(dates) %>% 
    rownames_to_column(var = "s_n")

17/12/2021, 17:10 - +234 816 062 6971: In case you know a girl in Nigeria who may be interested. Itâ€™s a competitive but rewarding experience. 

U.S. Department of State TechGirls Program 2022 for next generation of young women in STEM (Fully Funded to the United States)

Application Deadline: 
January 15, 2022 

https://techgirlsglobal.org/program/overview-2/ 

TechGirls connects and supports the next generation of women leaders in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics by providing them access and opportunities to advance their skills and pursue their dreams.

The core of the program is a 27-day experience in the United States in partnership with Virginia Tech University (tentatively scheduled for July 2022). TechGirls participate in an interactive technology and computer camp, then travel to one of the following cities (Austin, Chicago, Cincinnati, Denver, Detroit, Portland or Seattle) for job shadowing at a tech company, and homestay and community service experiences. The TechGirls programming yields a multiplier effect as participants return home to educate their peers and create community based projects.

Requirements

Are between the ages of 15 and 17 at the start of the exchange July 7th, 2022;
Have demonstrated advanced skills and a serious interest in technology, engineering, and/or math in their academic studies;
Intend to pursue higher education and/or careers in technology;
Have strong English language skills;
Exhibit maturity, flexibility, and open-mindedness;
Will attend at least one additional semester of secondary school upon their return to their home country; and
Are committed to completing a community-based project upon their return home.

Covered Costs
The TechGirls program covers the following costs:

Visa Fee
Roundtrip international airfare from participant home country to the United States
Housing during program
Double occupancy dormitory accommodations
Meals during program
Breakfast, lunch, and dinner
Local transportation to group program events
Cultural events organized by Legacy International
Emergency health insurance

The UK has a visa scheme for people in tech & you qualify if you're any of these: 

Data scientists/ engineers 

Digital Marketing experts 

Experienced UX/UI designers 

Cybersecurity experts 

Hardware engineers 

Experienced front-end developers 

Operating systems engineers


DevOps / SysOps engineers
Principal software engineers/developers 

Artificial Intelligence, Natural Language
Processing and Machine Learning experts (AI, NLP, ML) 

Experienced video game developers 

Experienced Mobile App developers 

Experienced back end developers 

If you have any of these business skills, you also qualify: 

Experience as a commercial/business lead (P&L, growth, sales and distribution strategy) in a digital business 

Experience of expanding or growing a significant product-led digital technology business 

Sector-specific experience e.g. payment infrastructure in FinTech / international expansion in EdTech etc. 

Solution sales experts 

Experienced Product Manager 

SaaS or enterprise sales leadership for digital services 

Solution sales skills performed for a growing B2B digital business (i.e. not big-company experience) 

Performance marketing experts, performed in house for digital businesses 

Experienced and senior VC or PE analysts with track records of leading investments in digital businesses 

Experienced and senior VC or PE analysts with track records of leading investments in digital businesses 

Experience as C Suite in a SMEs + (CEO, CMO, CIO) or head of operations for a digital business 

There are two options for applicants applying for endorsement by Tech Nation: 

Leader (called â€˜exceptional talentâ€™) 

Emerging leader (called â€˜exceptional promiseâ€™) 

Exceptional promise applicants are likely to be earlier in their career, usually with less than 5 years of experience. You must be able to prove your potential to be a leader through your skills & achievements 

Applicants must either: 

Meet one mandatory & two optional â€œExceptional Talentâ€ criteriaÂ  below 

OR 

Meet one mandatory & two optional â€œExceptional Promiseâ€ criteria in below 

Exceptional Talent
(leader in relevant field) 

An applicant evidencing EXCEPTIONAL TALENT must: 

show that they have been recognised as a leading talent in the digital technology sector And provide evidence of 2 of the following: 

a proven track record for innovation as a founder or senior executive of a product-led digital technology company or as an employee working on a new digital field or concept 

proof of recognition for work beyond the applicantâ€™s occupation that contributes to the advancement of the field they have made significant technical. 

commercial or entrepreneurial contributions to the field as a founder, senior executive, board member or employee of a product-led digital technology company 

they have demonstrated exceptional ability in the field by academic contributions through research published or endorsed by an expert. 

Exceptional Promise
(potential leader in relevant field) 

An applicant evidencing EXCEPTIONAL PROMISE must: 

show they have been recognised as having potential to be a leading talent in the digital technology field 

And provide evidence of 2 of the following: 

at least 1 example of innovation as a founder of a product led digital technology company or as an employee working on a new digital field or concept 

at least 1 example of proof of recognition for work beyond the applicantâ€™s occupation that contributes to the advancement of the field. 

at least 1 example of significant technical, commercial or entrepreneurial contributions to the field as a founder or employee of a product-led digital technology company 

at least 1 example of exceptional ability in the field by academic contributions through research endorsed by an expert. 

To apply for endorsement, visit: 

https://www.gov.uk/global-talent-digital-technology/apply-for-endorsement 

After that, complete a Tech Nation Visa application form for assessment here: 

https://tech-nation-visa.smapply.io/prog/tech_nation_visa_application/

31/12/2021, 00:23 - +234 708 531 6273: This road map can be confusing for beginners.  Just tools here and there. Even the poster no know half.ğŸ˜…
Companies and their processes are different.

As big and complex as my company's projects are, we only use Git(BitBucket),Docker,Terraform, Python and AWS(S3,Kinesis,Lambda,SNS,Glue, DynamoDB). 
Having a quality DE experience with any tool/processes doesnâ€™t make you less of a DE. I know DEs that what their companies do majorly is Dimensional Modelling. They are still DEs abi ğŸ˜…

Just focus on gathering quality DE experience irrespective of the tools/area and you will be fine.

04/01/2022, 22:45 - +234 708 531 6273: The most predictable and stable aspect of DE in almost all companies is Cloud Data Warehousing. It is one thing consistent in all DE job postings I have seen. 

Learn how to ingest data(using any ingestion tool you want) into a cloud data warehouse (Big Query,Redshift or snowflake). Learn to use DBT to transform the data. Learn Data Modelling. Learn an orchestration tool like Airflow.

After that, then move to data engineering on the cloud. Use the cloud services offered by any cloud provider of your choice to repeat the above Pipeline. 

In-between, while trying to achieve the above, you will have learnt things like Docker(Make sure you run those tools as a container) ,Python(While using pyspark or writing codes in AWS Lambda),SQL, Terraform (You will use it to deploy those AWS/Azure services as a code),Git (Version control for your code) and Bash(while using GIT and doing containerization). 

Don't try to learn this last part in isolation (except maybe Python and SQL).  Learn them while try to achieve things in the first part. 

If any one can painstakingly do this, oops ......

05/01/2022, 13:01 - Muhammed: Well for me sha:

1. Before I start de write my code, I de use docstring to give detailed explanation of what I want/hope to achieve.
2. I use inline commenting for every line of code (not in all cases though).
3. Where I have issues; I take my time to give detailed approach to how I was able to overcome the problem (using docstring). This is not done always sha, but I try to do it often.
4. I ensure that I apply spacing in code such that it is easy to read for anyone and everyone (myself inclusive).
5. Mostly, I test while writing the code, I keep only the working codes, but I often document challenges; including the shitty codes (they're kept in the docstring). Someone might find a way around the shitty codes.
05/01/2022, 13:01 - Muhammed: I do these often, but not all of the time sha â˜¹ï¸

04/02/2022, 04:12 - +234 810 878 6913: PARENTS

If you must get your children Android Portable Devices, you need to follow the below steps to be safe:

1. Register a gmail account for them with the correct age and with your email as the parent.

2. Install Google Family Link on your own phone.

3. Add their registered e-mail to your Google Family Link.

4. Factory Reset their android device if they already have one then login the device with their own gmail account that is linked to your Google Family Link. 

5. If it is new device, make sure it is their gmail you use to activate the device.

6. Immediately you carry out step 4 & 5 above, your phone will get a notification to allow them activate the device, this is the beginning of you taking control from anywhere. 

7. All adult content of any form will never load in their phone.

8. They cannot install anything without your approval remotely from the Family Link.

9. You can lock their device from anywhere.

10. You can set a start and stop time for their device usage, the phone will lock when it gets to that time even if you forget.

11. YouTube will not allow them see adult content too.

12. There is also YKids, which is YouTube for Kids, I recommend you remove the normal YouTube and give them YKids.

13. From your Google Family Link, you can see how long they stayed on each app or page to warn them where necessary. 

14. You will see as much as major details of the app.

Dear Parents, let's protect the morality of our Children.

16/02/2022, 14:39 - +234 809 183 1446: I recently installed dbt on windows..

Doing pip dbt install wasn't working.

So, I used this

pip install \
  dbt-core \
  dbt-postgres \
  dbt-redshift \
  dbt-snowflake \
  dbt-bigquery

This link also helped
https://www.dataduel.co/install-dbt-on-win10-april-2021/
